# Confer Instance of BoxyHQ Jackson

## Workflow

This is primarily used for Idp Initiated SSO from NCR. We would be the SP in this instance. We have configured a connection with them, providing them with our configuration located [here](https://auth.conferlending.com/.well-known/saml-configuration). They are utilizing the public encryption certificate to encrypt the data before sending over.

They are not providing SSO links in their Idp Metadata as we do not have an SP initiated flow setup with them.

In order to test out an Idp Initiated flow, we did do a trial run with OKTA, but it has expired since then. In order to configure it, on the boxy side of things, we added our

### Allowed redirect URLs (newline separated):

```
https://app.conferlending.com
```

### Default redirect URL

```
https://app.conferlending.com/login/saml
```

The default redirect URL is where the user would go from an Idp initiated login, hence the url on the front end that receives the code query string param.

### Tenant

We set a tenant name of conferlending.com though this isn't needed for Idp initiated either. This would be for SP initiated only as a user would theoretically click something like 'login with email' and we would grab the email @ address and find the corresponding tenant to login with.

### Product

This would also be used for SP initiated flow only. This flow for example using next-auth would pass both the tenant and product and then pass those to jackson, which would then find the corresponding Idp to login with. In the example we did, OKTA.

### Idp Metadata

This is required for the auth connection between this SSO gateway and the Idp provider. This will be provided by the Idp, in our case NCR. If we were setting up okta, it would create the metadata after we inputted all of our info from the configuration page mentioned above.

### Testing / Debugging

To work through the issues found during initial setup with NCR, had to figure out a lot of things on how this system worked. The Idp posts to the endpoint

```
/api/oauth/saml
```

What is posted is the xml payload that is encrypted with and then base64 encoded. To debug, we have payloads that have been sent from NCR in our email with our vendor contact Richard. First take the xml payload, put it in an file in vscode with a .xml extension and save it to run prettier. If prettier fails, it is most likely an issue with quotations and not in the correct format. After it is in the correct format, use any base64 encoder online and get the encoded string.

After you have the encoded string, you should be able to post to our endpoint locally

```
localhost:5225/api/oauth/saml
```

using postman and choosing the `x-www-urlencoded` body type. Then have a key of `SAMLResponse` and a value of the encoded string. For example

```

```

You also may notice that this repo is setup somewhat as a mono repo with references to `@boxyhq/saml-jackson` and other items as if they are npm packages coming from npm. Though they are located in npm to pull down, you can change the reference to a relative `../npm` in order to set breakpoints. For example change

```
import jackson from '@boxyhq/saml-jackson';
```

to

```
import jackson from '../npm';
```

or whatever relative path is correct.

### SAML20

While debugging you may notice that a lot of the xml parsing is done from a library referenced as saml20. We have also forked this repository to make sure we have in Github. If you need to, you can make local changes to that library, build it and then manually copy the changed file into the the node_modules folder of this repo. For some reason the folder does not display in vscode so you may have to do it in finder. You then might also have to delete the next cache for it to be picked up again. At root of directory look for it in

```
$ cd .next
$ ls
```

and you should see `cache`.

I made one change while debugging xml inside of saml20 to bypass the check for expired token of course. You may have to do this whenever you debug. Look for the error `Assertion is expired.` inside of `lib/response.ts` inside of the saml20 repository.
